question.title: A method to reverse effect of java String.split()?

node.contents: I am looking for a method to combine an array of strings into a delimited String. An opposite to split(). I've seen this in other languages.

node.contents: I wrote this one:

astNode.text: I wrote this one:

elements.contents: public static String join(Collection<String> col, String delim) { StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder(); Iterator<String> iter = col.iterator(); if (iter.hasNext()) sb.append(iter.next()); while (iter.hasNext()) { sb.append(delim); sb.append(iter.next()); } return sb.toString(); }

units.rawText: public static String join(Collection<String> col, String delim) { StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder(); Iterator<String> iter = col.iterator(); if (iter.hasNext()) sb.append(iter.next()); while (iter.hasNext()) { sb.append(delim); sb.append(iter.next()); } return sb.toString(); }

node.contents: Collection isn't supported by JSP, so for TLD I wrote:

astNode.text: Collection isn't supported by JSP, so for TLD I wrote:

elements.contents: public static String join(List<?> list, String delim) { int len = list.size(); if (len == 0) return ""; StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder(list.get(0).toString()); for (int i = 1; i < len; i++) { sb.append(delim); sb.append(list.get(i).toString()); } return sb.toString(); }

units.rawText: public static String join(List<?> list, String delim) { int len = list.size(); if (len == 0) return ""; StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder(list.get(0).toString()); for (int i = 1; i < len; i++) { sb.append(delim); sb.append(list.get(i).toString()); } return sb.toString(); }

node.contents: A bit late, but that sounds like a generally bad idea, unless you know with absolute certainty that there can never be a ', ' in your strings. And then it's probably far from efficient.

astNode.text: A bit late, but that sounds like a generally bad idea, unless you know with absolute certainty that there can never be a ', ' in your strings. And then it's probably far from efficient.

node.contents: You can sneak this functionality out of the Arrays utility package.

astNode.text: You can sneak this functionality out of the Arrays utility package.

elements.contents: import java.util.Arrays; ... String delim = ":", csv_record = "Field0:Field1:Field2", fields[] = csv_record.split(delim); String rebuilt_record = Arrays.toString(fields).replace(", ", delim).replaceAll("[\\[\\]]", "");

node.contents: There's no method in the JDK for this that I'm aware of. Apache Commons Lang has various overloaded join() methods in the StringUtils class that do what you want.

astNode.text: There's no method in the JDK for this that I'm aware of. Apache Commons Lang has various overloaded join() methods in the StringUtils class that do what you want.

node.contents: For Android: in android.text.TextUtils there are methods:

astNode.text: For Android: in android.text.TextUtils there are methods:

elements.contents: public static String join (CharSequence delimiter, Iterable tokens) public static String join (CharSequence delimiter, Object[] tokens)

units.rawText: public static String join (CharSequence delimiter, Iterable tokens) public static String join (CharSequence delimiter, Object[] tokens)

node.contents: Returns a string containing the tokens joined by delimiters.

astNode.text: Returns a string containing the tokens joined by delimiters.

node.contents: tokens -- an array objects to be joined. Strings will be formed from the objects by calling object.toString().

astNode.text: tokens -- an array objects to be joined. Strings will be formed from the objects by calling object.toString().

node.contents: I got the following example here

astNode.text: I got the following example here

elements.contents: /* 7) Join Strings using separator >>>AB$#$CD$#$EF */ import org.apache.commons.lang.StringUtils; public class StringUtilsTrial { public static void main(String[] args) { // Join all Strings in the Array into a Single String, separated by $#$ System.out.println("7) Join Strings using separator >>>" + StringUtils.join(new String[] { "AB", "CD", "EF" }, "$#$")); } }

comments.text: // Join all Strings in the Array into a Single String, separated by $#$ System.out.println("7) Join Strings using separator >>>" + StringUtils.join(new String[] { "AB", "CD", "EF" }, "$#$")); } }

node.contents: I think this is the better way to do it, simple and efficient. Also to be mentioned is that apache use a simple for with a if inside and openjdk8 do something like yours but in separated methods.

astNode.text: I think this is the better way to do it, simple and efficient. Also to be mentioned is that apache use a simple for with a if inside and openjdk8 do something like yours but in separated methods.

node.contents: Based on all the previous answers:

astNode.text: Based on all the previous answers:

elements.contents: public static String join(Iterable<? extends Object> elements, CharSequence separator) { StringBuilder builder = new StringBuilder(); if (elements != null) { Iterator<? extends Object> iter = elements.iterator(); if(iter.hasNext()) { builder.append( String.valueOf( iter.next() ) ); while(iter.hasNext()) { builder .append( separator ) .append( String.valueOf( iter.next() ) ); } } } return builder.toString(); }

units.rawText: public static String join(Iterable<? extends Object> elements, CharSequence separator) { StringBuilder builder = new StringBuilder(); if (elements != null) { Iterator<? extends Object> iter = elements.iterator(); if(iter.hasNext()) { builder.append( String.valueOf( iter.next() ) ); while(iter.hasNext()) { builder .append( separator ) .append( String.valueOf( iter.next() ) ); } } } return builder.toString(); }

node.contents: I think that many of the answer here are complex or not easily read. With branch prediction so efficient why you simply not use a if statement?

astNode.text: I think that many of the answer here are complex or not easily read. With branch prediction so efficient why you simply not use a if statement?

elements.contents: public static String join(List<String> fooList){ if (fooList.isEmpty()) return ""; StringBuilder sb = null; for (String element : fooList) { if (sb == null) { sb = new StringBuilder(); } else { sb.append(", "); } sb.append(element); } return sb.toString(); }

units.rawText: public static String join(List<String> fooList){ if (fooList.isEmpty()) return ""; StringBuilder sb = null; for (String element : fooList) { if (sb == null) { sb = new StringBuilder(); } else { sb.append(", "); } sb.append(element); } return sb.toString(); }

node.contents: To be mentioned is that apache use a simple for with a if inside like this (it use an array an its index to know the first element) and openjdk8 do the same but in separated methods calls instead of a simple loop.

astNode.text: To be mentioned is that apache use a simple for with a if inside like this (it use an array an its index to know the first element) and openjdk8 do the same but in separated methods calls instead of a simple loop.

node.contents: Actually this works for String[] too, using Arrays.toString(Object[]) This has been available since Java 1.5 which was released in 2004 _eons_ before the question was posted. This is the **correct** answer, if you don't mind the prefix "[" and suffix "]".

astNode.text: Actually this works for String[] too, using Arrays.toString(Object[]) This has been available since Java 1.5 which was released in 2004 _eons_ before the question was posted. This is the **correct** answer, if you don't mind the prefix "[" and suffix "]".

node.contents: If you have an int[], Arrays.toString() is the easiest way.

astNode.text: If you have an int[], Arrays.toString() is the easiest way.

node.contents: There has been an open feature request since at least 2009. The long and short of it is that it will part of the functionality of JDK 8's java.util.StringJoiner class. http://download.java.net/lambda/b81/docs/api/java/util/StringJoiner.html

astNode.text: There has been an open feature request since at least 2009. The long and short of it is that it will part of the functionality of JDK 8's java.util.StringJoiner class. http://download.java.net/lambda/b81/docs/api/java/util/StringJoiner.html

node.contents: Here is an example of the new JDK 8 StringJoiner on an array of String

astNode.text: Here is an example of the new JDK 8 StringJoiner on an array of String

elements.contents: String[] a = new String[]{"first","second","third"}; StringJoiner sj = new StringJoiner(","); for(String s:a) sj.add(s); System.out.println(sj); //first,second,third

units.rawText: String[] a = new String[]{"first","second","third"}; StringJoiner sj = new StringJoiner(","); for(String s:a) sj.add(s); Systemoutprintln(sj); //first,second,third

astNode.text: @allyourcode I think `StringBuffer` usage avoids the Schlemiel problem [link](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Schlemiel_the_Painter%27s_algorithm)

node.contents: This one is not bad too :

astNode.text: This one is not bad too :

elements.contents: public static String join(String delimitor,String ... subkeys) { String result = null; if(null!=subkeys && subkeys.length>0) { StringBuffer joinBuffer = new StringBuffer(subkeys[0]); for(int idx=1;idx<subkeys.length;idx++) { joinBuffer.append(delimitor).append(subkeys[idx]); } result = joinBuffer.toString(); } return result; }

units.rawText: public static String join(String delimitor,String ... subkeys) { String result = null; if(null!=subkeys && subkeys.length>0) { StringBuffer joinBuffer = new StringBuffer(subkeys[0]); for(int idx=1;idx<subkeys.length;idx++) { joinBuffer.append(delimitor).append(subkeys[idx]); } result = joinBuffer.toString(); } return result; }

node.contents: For the sake of completeness, I'd like to add that you cannot reverse String#split in general, as it accepts a regular expression.

astNode.text: For the sake of completeness, I'd like to add that you cannot reverse String#split in general, as it accepts a regular expression.

node.contents:
"hello__world".split("_+"); Yields ["hello", "world"].
"hello_world".split("_+"); Yields ["hello", "world"].

astNode.text:
"hello__world".split("_+"); Yields ["hello", "world"].
"hello_world".split("_+"); Yields ["hello", "world"].

node.contents: These yield identical results from a different starting point. splitting is not a one-to-one operation, and is thus non-reversible.

astNode.text: These yield identical results from a different starting point. splitting is not a one-to-one operation, and is thus non-reversible.

node.contents: This all being said, if you assume your parameter to be a fixed string, not regex, then you can certainly do this using one of the many posted answers.

astNode.text: This all being said, if you assume your parameter to be a fixed string, not regex, then you can certainly do this using one of the many posted answers.

node.contents: This suffers from the Schlemeil problem: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Schlemiel_the_Painter's_algorithm

astNode.text: This suffers from the Schlemeil problem: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Schlemiel_the_Painter's_algorithm

node.contents: @allyourcode I'd never heard of that problem before, thank you for the link!

astNode.text: @allyourcode I'd never heard of that problem before, thank you for the link!

node.contents: @allyourcode It's lucky that compilers 'move the paint can' for schmucks like Schlemeil nowadays.

astNode.text: @allyourcode It's lucky that compilers 'move the paint can' for schmucks like Schlemeil nowadays.

node.contents: I like this better:

astNode.text: I like this better:

elements.contents: public String join(Collection<String> strCollection, String delimiter) { String joined = ""; int noOfItems = 0; for (String item : strCollection) { joined += item; if (++noOfItems < strCollection.size()) joined += delimiter; } return joined; }

units.rawText: public String join(Collection<String> strCollection, String delimiter) { String joined = ""; int noOfItems = 0; for (String item : strCollection) { joined += item; if (++noOfItems < strCollection.size()) joined += delimiter; } return joined; }

node.contents: It is the neatest solution I have found so far. (Don't worry about the use of raw String objects instead of StringBuilder. Modern Java compilers use StringBuilder anyway, but this code is more readable).

astNode.text: It is the neatest solution I have found so far. (Don't worry about the use of raw String objects instead of StringBuilder. Modern Java compilers use StringBuilder anyway, but this code is more readable).

node.contents: I would be inclined to leave out the empty check, because the behavior will be the same and why complicate the code with special cases? On the other hand, a null check might be in order.

astNode.text: I would be inclined to leave out the empty check, because the behavior will be the same and why complicate the code with special cases? On the other hand, a null check might be in order.

node.contents: @Carl: I completely agree with you on the null check and added that. Checking for an empty Collection allows the function to skip needlessly creating an Iterator and a StringBuffer, so I left it in.

astNode.text: @Carl: I completely agree with you on the null check and added that. Checking for an empty Collection allows the function to skip needlessly creating an Iterator and a StringBuffer, so I left it in.

node.contents: You should use StringBuilder instead of StringBuffer as StringBuffer has the added overhead of being synchronized. You don't need synchronization for method variables (since only one thread will be using it).

astNode.text: You should use StringBuilder instead of StringBuffer as StringBuffer has the added overhead of being synchronized. You don't need synchronization for method variables (since only one thread will be using it).

node.contents: @Steve: Agreed and updated.

astNode.text: @Steve: Agreed and updated.

node.contents: Your join method should accept Collection, not AbstractCollection. Better yet, it could accept Iterable, which allows it to be more generic.

astNode.text: Your join method should accept Collection, not AbstractCollection. Better yet, it could accept Iterable, which allows it to be more generic.

node.contents: @Steve: Either of those would be acceptable. You can make it as abstract or specific as you need. There's a later example on the page I linked to that accepts Iterable.

astNode.text: @Steve: Either of those would be acceptable. You can make it as abstract or specific as you need. There's a later example on the page I linked to that accepts Iterable.

node.contents:
You can also use the "
<!--? extends Object-->" generic type along with "iter.next().toString()" to be able to join string representation of Integers and other types.

node.contents: There are several examples on DZone Snippets if you want to roll your own that works with a Collection. For example:

astNode.text: There are several examples on DZone Snippets if you want to roll your own that works with a Collection. For example:

elements.contents: public static String join(AbstractCollection<String> s, String delimiter) { if (s == null || s.isEmpty()) return ""; Iterator<String> iter = s.iterator(); StringBuilder builder = new StringBuilder(iter.next()); while( iter.hasNext() ) { builder.append(delimiter).append(iter.next()); } return builder.toString(); }

units.rawText: public static String join(AbstractCollection<String> s, String delimiter) { if (s == null|| s.isEmpty()) return ""; Iterator<String> iter = s.iterator(); StringBuilder builder = new StringBuilder(iter.next()); while( iter.hasNext() ) { builder.append(delimiter).append(iter.next()); } return builder.toString(); }
